Award.AwardTitle: EAGER: Experimental Investigation of Forced Convection on Hierarchical Micro/Nanoporous Conducting-Lubricating Surfaces

Division.LongName: Div Of Chem, Bioeng, Env, & Transp Sys

Award.AbstractNarration:
CBET-1449621
Kota (New Mexico State University)


Forced convection heat transfer has a very wide application base. It is inherent to numerous processes and equipment that affect our day-to-day lives such as heat exchangers and heat sinks in power generation, thermal management, space transportation, water purification and defense sectors. In forced convection of liquids in channels/pipes, due to the analogous dependence of flow friction and heat transfer performance on fluid flow velocity and wall/surface characteristics, it was found by prior researchers that any attempt to lower friction at the walls inevitably results in decreased heat transfer rate and efforts to augment heat transfer almost always result in increased frictional flow resistance. While enhanced heat transfer is beneficial, increased friction at the walls demands more electricity consumption in the form of pumping power required to overcome it. This proposal aims to resolve this important and arduous problem that has attracted much research attention in the last few decades i.e., it enables friction reduction near the walls for fluid flow but for the first time, with negligible impact on heat transfer performance by employing liquid-saturated hierarchical micro/nanoporous surfaces. The focus will be on forced convection of liquids without phase change. The proposed work has broader impacts on science and society, which will be demonstrated through curriculum integration and state-of-the-art research/classroom opportunities at the undergraduate and graduate levels at the New Mexico State University. This activity will directly help in developing a diverse, globally competitive STEM workforce that would understand and address critical issues of national interest in energy.

For achieving the project goals and objectives, robust hierarchical micro/nanoporous surfaces of various roughness topologies will be fabricated on internal surfaces of flow channels using a novel etching technique, and their wetting, aging, and robustness aspects will be characterized using precise weight measurement and fluorescence microscopy techniques. To verify the theoretical predictions that showed substantial potential of the concept, experimental investigation of forced convective heat transfer performance of common coolants will be carried out in mini/microchannels with water saturating the micro/nanoporous wall surfaces. The recorded data of pressures, temperatures and flow rates will be post-processed to obtain an energy-efficiency metric, which will be the increased Nusselt number for the same pumping power required to pump the same liquid through a same sized channel with regular/smooth surfaces. Outcomes as a result of successful completion of the project will generate new knowledge base for realizing significant energy efficiencies in forced convective transport by providing novel fundamental insights on surface -philicity and robustness, flow stability and thermal transport, and their dependence on surface topology.

POR.DRECONTENT:
There are numerous heat transfer applications that involve a liquid flowing through a pipe or a channel. Some examples are: hot and cold liquids exchaging heat while flowing through an industrial heat exchanger, a liquid flowing through a cold plate attached to a hot component in a data center server, coolant flowing through the radiator of an automobile while dissipating heat to ambient, liquid flowing through a pipe absorbing heat from the Sun in a solar power plant etc. In these applications, it is beneficial to increase the amount of heat transferred from/to the flowing liquid. Heat transfer from/to a flowing liquid can be increased by either increasing its velocity and/or the contact surface area between the channel walls and the liquid (i.e., by making the surfaces rougher) and/or by inducing mixing in the flow. However, all these options are associated with a penalty of increased pump power consumption. The pump that pushes the liquid through these channels has to overcome the friction between the liquid and the walls of the channels. The heat transfer enhancements described above further increase the flow and surface friction, and the pump has to work much harder to push the liquid. In summary, it was found by prior researchers that any attempt to improve heat transfer is almost always associated with an increased pump power consumption or vice versa i.e., attempts to decrease the pump power consumption by reducing the friction at the channel walls will lower the heat transfer performance. In many applications, the pump energy consumption could be prohibitively large. Reducing the friction between a flowing liquid and the surfaces will save billions of dollars every year in pumping energy consumption. In addition, savings in the energy will also contribute to a reduced environmental carbon footprint.
            This project focused on a study of the potential of novel Conducting-Lubricating (CO-LUB) surfaces in lowering the pumping power but without negatively impacting the heat transfer performance. The idea is to infuse the solid surfaces of a flow channel with a very thin layer of a low viscous liquid. This microlayer of the liquid will act as a lubricant to the more viscous bulk liquid flowing over these surfaces thereby reduing friction while simultaneously facilitating conduction or transfer of heat between the surfaces and the bulk liquid.
            The viability of this idea was tested in this project through experiments. A channel was prepared with copper surfaces that can hold the microlayer liquid with strong capillary forces. Many robustness tests were performed to ensure these copper surfaces retain the microlayer liquid when another liquid flows over it. Water was used as the microlayer liquid. The surfaces were first saturated with water to form the CO-LUB surfaces and mineral oil (i.e., the bulk liquid) was then pumped over these surfaces in a flow channel. Under the conditions of the experiments, it was observed that, compared to the flow of mineral oil through a plain-walled channel (without CO-LUB surfaces), the pumping power consumption was significantly reduced for its flow through a CO-LUB-walled channel. The more important result is that this reduced pump power consumption was not associated with the traditional decrease in the heat transfer performance. On the contrary, since water in the CO-LUB surfaces provided lubrication to mineral oil and reduced friction, the latter was found to flow with a higher velocity, which resulted in improved heat transfer performance.
             This project demonstrated the practicability of preparing and implementing CO-LUB surfaces for liquid flows through channels. CO-LUB surfaces tightly hold water due to strong capillary forces. The strong capillary forces were generated using a new surface modification technology that imparts hierarchical roughness at micro- and nano-scale level to metallic surfaces. Videos of water droplets wetting and spreading on these surfaces (similar to a paper towel) are uploaded to the YouTube channel, SIRE Lab. Further testing of these surfaces under a broader set of experimental conditions will be carried out in the future.
             The success of this project is attributed to the numerous students who worked on this project at the New Mexico State University (NMSU). Two graduate students and 23 undergraduate students were involved in this project. Of the 23 undergraduate students, two were involved as research assistants while the remaining students participated through the senior design course offered by the Department of Mechanical and Aerospace Engineering at NMSU. These students were trained by the graduate students and the PI to provide them exciting engineering/science research experience and insight on micro-manufacturing and applications of copper surfaces with altered wetting properties. The graduate students were involved in publications and presentation of the results at international conferences. By working on this project and training the undergraduate students, the graduate students gained invaluable research and teaching experience and obtained master's degrees by successfully defending their theses based on this research.
